description:
This fixes Issue #979. This has no effect on the field_info that ends up getting set up, it just removes the warnings.

I have also moved the "field already exists" warning so that it doesn't get triggered internally, as Nathan suggested. It still gets triggered in user scripts, as shown [here](http://nbviewer.ipython.org/gist/atmyers/175219bcfdffe9a6062d).
title: removing unneeded field aliases in the enzo frontend

pullrequest.title: removing unneeded field aliases in the enzo frontend

pullrequest.title: removing unneeded field aliases in the enzo frontend

content.raw:
It looks like a lot of the warnings are being triggered by duplicate calls to `add_field` in `fluid_fields.py`. This happens when the frontend defines a custom version of a field that is also defined in `fluid_fields.py`.  Since we set up the frontend fields before the fluid field registry, the calls to `add_field` in `fluid_fields.py` are no-ops and throw the `force_override` warning you added.

While the aliases corrected in this PR are useless and should be fixed, what do you think about moving the warning for `force_override=True` over to the `add_field` implementation in `local_fields.py`?  This is the version of `add_field` that people see in user scripts.  You could also add a warning for `StaticOutput.add_field`.

I think having the warning in the add_field implementation in the base `FieldInfoContainer` and preventing errors from showing up by explicitly checking if a field has already been added class would make field definitions needlessly tedious. Since we don't know ahead of time what fields frontend maintainers might like to implement as a special case for their frontend, almost every derived field that yt defines internally would need to be wrapped with `if field not in registry` clauses before calling `add_field`.  Other uglier options are possible, like monkey-patching add-field for some subset of fields we expect frontend maintainers to implement.

While I agree that the warning is very useful for user scripts, it's awkward to deal with internally in yt.  Given that we have the correct behavior right now - we defer to the field definition in the code frontend if one exists - I think it's ok to allow duplicate calls to add_field internally, especially given how noisy these warnings can be.
content.html:
It looks like a lot of the warnings are being triggered by duplicate calls to add_field in fluid_fields.py. This happens when the frontend defines a custom version of a field that is also defined in fluid_fields.py. Since we set up the frontend fields before the fluid field registry, the calls to add_field in fluid_fields.py are no-ops and throw the force_override warning you added.

While the aliases corrected in this PR are useless and should be fixed, what do you think about moving the warning for force_override=True over to the add_field implementation in local_fields.py? This is the version of add_field that people see in user scripts. You could also add a warning for StaticOutput.add_field.

I think having the warning in the add_field implementation in the base FieldInfoContainer and preventing errors from showing up by explicitly checking if a field has already been added class would make field definitions needlessly tedious. Since we don't know ahead of time what fields frontend maintainers might like to implement as a special case for their frontend, almost every derived field that yt defines internally would need to be wrapped with if field not in registry clauses before calling add_field. Other uglier options are possible, like monkey-patching add-field for some subset of fields we expect frontend maintainers to implement.

While I agree that the warning is very useful for user scripts, it's awkward to deal with internally in yt. Given that we have the correct behavior right now - we defer to the field definition in the code frontend if one exists - I think it's ok to allow duplicate calls to add_field internally, especially given how noisy these warnings can be.

content.html: For some reason, I thought this was necessary. Maybe it is if we have a particle type other than io?

pullrequest.title: removing unneeded field aliases in the enzo frontend

content.raw: Yeah, you're right. The internal field setup system is designed to have redundant calls to add_field, and at the end of the day everything gets added correctly, so the warnings aren't necessary. I can try out moving the warning and add that to this PR, if that's okay with you.
content.html: Yeah, you're right. The internal field setup system is designed to have redundant calls to add_field, and at the end of the day everything gets added correctly, so the warnings aren't necessary. I can try out moving the warning and add that to this PR, if that's okay with you.

pullrequest.title: removing unneeded field aliases in the enzo frontend

content.raw: I also tried [this](http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5477/) script out on the Enzo ActiveParticles dataset, which has "DarkMatter" and "CenOstriker" particle types, and it also gives the same output before and after this changeset is applied.  Does that address your concern?
content.html: I also tried this script out on the Enzo ActiveParticles dataset, which has "DarkMatter" and "CenOstriker" particle types, and it also gives the same output before and after this changeset is applied. Does that address your concern?

content.raw: Shoot, I merged this but just now noticed that using `pop` here will mean that force_override is not being passed down to the superclass implementation.
content.html: Shoot, I merged this but just now noticed that using pop here will mean that force_override is not being passed down to the superclass implementation.
